data.text: Best Rotor/Pad Combo for Long, Steep Mountain Descents

Best rotor/pad combo for long, steep mountain descents? Shimano GRX 400 on a Cannondale Topstone. Getting more comfortable at higher speeds but I still want brakes that I can depend on when it gets hot!
I e got the 800 series calipers, whatever pads those came with have been fantastic!
data.author: Cory Rood

data.text: 400 and 800 I think are the same anyway... maybe different pads?
data.author: Jeremy Schwab

data.text: if you want/need MORE braking power - Trickstuff !
data.author: Larry Narachi

data.text: metal pads. Metal pads work better at high heat. Organic pads work better on brake tapping on/off type of stuff ,low heat. LONG descents where you're on the brakes for real, look for metal pads. They'll last longer, too.
data.author: Dave Chase

data.text: Sure you need more? Me + bike ~200#, and we go down plenty of long and steep paved & unpaved road. 140/160 rear/front rotors. SRAM Force hydro brakes with organic pads. Doesn’t sound like a good combo but have never had overheating, and I know what overheating is like bc I intentionally did it just to see. Long steep grade slow no cooling front only eventually got the whiff. Have never gotten it when not trying to burn them.
data.author: Dave Wright

data.text: I went down one mountain road today and somehow managed to glaze the pads. Maybe I was braking too hard?
data.author: Richard J. Auchus

data.text: for sure equipment and technique vary and produce diff results. I thought you were maybe being cautious, but if you’re already getting glaze then should look at equipment options like you are. Should first change to sintered / metal pads. Organics are often OEM bc they are quieter, have good feel, and wear your rotors more slowly. Sintered are more heat resistant and can handle harder use without glazing though. If that doesn’t do the job, next more expensive step is larger diameter rotors, prob only need front. Beyond that maybe change to 4 piston brakes.
data.author: Dave Wright

data.text: Additional comment. Organic pads, which are my choice, def wear out faster. I ride some steep and loose roads that have to be taken slowly. got only 2500 miles out of my last pad set. Due to supply problems, good to always have spare set on hand.
data.author: Dave Wright

data.text: Sram or Shimano hydraulic roads brakes with 160mm rotors are plenty for most people. If your heavier, more aggressive or ride abnormally long steep descents going up to 180mm rotors and/or 4 piston MTB calipers would give you very powerful brakes
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: Add Shimano rotors but not just any rotors. Make sure they are the XT or ultegra level IceTech rotors. They'll make a huge difference. And take the time to bed in the pads and rotors properly.
data.author: Thad Sparrow

data.text: a lot of people recommend ice tech. Are they really that good?
data.author: Richard J. Auchus

data.text: significantly better. No matter what brake system you run, run the ice tech rotors. I run Ice Tech rotors with Kogel Kratos pads and Apex calipers. Shit-tons of power. The stock Apex set up is for shit. I'm a 200 plus pound dude with moto sports and DH background. This is the way...
data.author: Thad Sparrow

data.text: disagree. the shimano rotors have a steel face over aluminum core and warp more easily when hot. had to take the dura ace rotors off the road bike to sram to stop the rubbing on descents. also metal pads trade pad life for rotor life, i.e. metal pads last longer but you’ll be changing rotors more often.
data.author: Will Zemba

data.text: "8" series rotors like the ultegra or xt are truly fantastic. The "9" series like DA or XTR can be problematic. They tend to prioritize weight reduction over durability. I would never recommend the DA or XTR rotors. Not worth the extra expense.
data.author: Thad Sparrow

data.text: I have the 4 piston deore calipers. Huge stopping power. Better than my 2 piston Rivals for sure. Also Shimano ice tech rotors, vs. whatever cheapies.
data.author: Chris Summers
